metadata.title: Title: No Evidence for Temperature-Dependence of the COVID-19 Epidemic 1 Running Title: Temperature-independence of COVID-19 Epidemic 2

body_text.text: extending between 30 o N and 50 o N (Sajadi et al., 2020) , now in late winter, leading to the 26 suggestion, echoed by the global media, that the epidemic is likely to be temperature-27 dependent. This supported speculation of possible decline in severity with the advent of 28 warmer spring and summer temperatures in north-temperate latitudes (Sajadi et al., 29 2020; Wang et al., 2020) , comparable to many viruses affecting human respiratory systems, 30 including SARS (Tan et al., 2005; Gaunt et al., 2010) . 31
However, recent (updated up to March 26, 2020; cf. Methods) data revealed the 32 spread of the epidemic across territories experiencing warm temperatures in the tropics (e.g. 33
Indonesia, Singapore, Brazil) and southern hemisphere as well (e.g. Australia, Argentina). 34

The current distribution of the epidemic challenges, therefore, the inference that SARS-CoV-35 2 may behave as a seasonal respiratory virus based on previous statistical analyses from 36 earlier realized distributions. 37

Here we examine the relationship between the apparent exponential rate of SARS-38 The number of COVID-19 incidences follows the expected exponential growth, 57 although rates are only robust when cases exceed 100 persons for any country or province. 58

Hence, we fitted the exponential model to each country and each province of China. We 59 calculated exponential rate parameters for the countries where the COVID-19 incident has at 60 least a 10-day growth period, and the total number of cases was at least 100. 61
Where N is the cumulative number of diagnosed persons and Days is the number of days and 64 ߛ is the exponential rate (100 x ߛ = % increase per day). 65
To calculate the effect of temperature on the exponential rate parameter, we first 67 regressed the exponential rate parameters retrieved from the exponential model on ܶ ݁ ݉ ‫‬ and 68
If the squared term is significant, it provides evidence of nonlinearity. 70

Surprisingly, ߛ and R0 across Chinese 97 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

is the (which was not peer-reviewed) The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.29.20046706 doi: medRxiv preprint provinces (mean ± SE = 4.1 ± 0.1 % day -1 and 1.09 ± 0.01) were well below those of other 98 nations (mean ± SE = 22.39 ± 0.94 % day -1 and 1.90 ± 0.07), possibly because much faster 99 confinement of the Chinese population did not allow for the potential exponential rates under 100 uncontrolled conditions to be realized. The broad variability in realized ߛ and R0 between 101 nations (global) and provinces (China) largely reflects differences in detection likelihood 102 along with the timing and rigour of adoption of confinement measures. 103

The relationship between ߛ and R0 and T avg shows no evidence for a reduced spread 104 rate with warming (Figure 1 and R0 for T avg > 20 o C ( Figure S2 ). Our updated results (Figure 1) show, however, that 110 this apparent temperature-dependence was confounded with a prevailing zonal pattern of 111 spread across the north-temperate zone, possibly reflecting the main patterns of human 112 mobility, which delayed arrival of the epidemics to the southern hemisphere and the tropics. 113

These results suggest that, contrary to prior assessments, the spread rate of the 115 COVID-19 pandemic is temperature-independent, suggesting that there is little hope for relief 116 as temperatures in the northern hemisphere increase, and that poor nations with weak health 117 systems in tropical regions, such as African, are at great risk. 118
Data sources: The data on COVID-19 is available publicly across many sources; where 119 downloadable data files are updated daily few are listed below; 120

TABREF0.text: CoV-2 spread (ߛ) and the Basic Reproductive number of infection (R0) and the average daily 39 temperature (T avg ) across nations and Chinese provinces where epidemics, with at least 100 40 case reported, have been reported (data updated up to 26 March, 2020). 41 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Cases Data 43 The Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) daily data are confirmed cases for affected 44 countries and provinces of China reported between 31st December 2019 to 26th March 2020. 45 The data was collected from the reports released by WHO, European Centre for Disease 46 Prevention and Control (ECDC), and John Hopkin CSSA. Data include confirmed and a 47 cumulative total of COVID-19 cases in affected countries/provinces. 48The average temperatures of all the affected countries were collected 51 from https://www.timeanddate.com/. The monthly mean temperature of February and the 52 three-weeks mean temperature of March of capital cities for the various nations were used as 53

Where, a (amplitude) is the 74 coefficient related to maximum of spread rate of countries, the optimum ‫)ݐ(‬ on the 75 temperature gradient is where the maximum of spread rate is attained and the tolerance ‫)݈ݐ(‬ 76gives the width of the response curve. This model has non-linear form, and the model 77performance curve was estimated by fitting Gaussian model to the growth rate and 79 temperature of infected countries. The initial values for the Gaussian parameters 80 Estimated the basic reproductive number (R0) for COVID-19 from China and other 83 countries using the Statistical exponential growth model method adopting serial interval from 84 an average of SARS (mean=8.4 days, SD=3.8 days) and MERS (mean=7.6 days, SD=3.4 85 days). All analyses were performed using R statistical computing software. 86Our results show that evidence for a temperature-dependence of the transmission 89 reported in previous papers was likely to be an artifact, reflecting the pathways of spread, and 90 that there is no evidence for thermal dependence of the transmission across the -10 to 31 o C 91 T avg range across the affected regions. This suggests little basis to expect evidence for the 92 virus to behave as a seasonal respiratory virus. 93Epidemiological data consisting in the rate of increase in accumulated diagnosed 94
